Description: Water systems may be required to monitor for PFOA and PFOS.
Developing appropriate testing protocols, health-based standards, proper messageing to the public.

Bill would prohibit the use of firefighting substances that contain PFAS (with certain exceptions). It would also require the state to accept for disposal up to 25 gallons of PFAS-containing firefighting foam annually per state resident.

The Department of Transportation and Public Facilities is conducting evaluation of PFAS at state-owned properties it is responsible for (including airports). The agency has responded to at least five communities with PFAS contamination.
Established levels of PFOA and PFOS at which water treatment or alternative water sources must be provided by responsible parties established at 70 parts per trillion.
Groundwater and surface water cleanup levels established at 0.40 micrograms/liters for PFOA and PFOS.
A rule proposed in October 2018 would amend the groundwater and surface water cleanup levels for PFOA and PFOS and set cleanup levels for PFBS, PFHpA, PFHxS and PFNA. The proposal is on hold.
Bill would require regulators to establish water quality standards for PFAS and other substances.
A one-year pilot program from the Arizona Department of Environmental Quality will remove, dispose, and replace PFAS-containing firefighting foam at no cost for select fire departments.
Notes: Program is funded through a $395,500 allocation in the FY 2023 budget

Description: Bans the use of intentionally added PFAS chemicals in class B firefighting foam for testing or training purposes except for testing in facilities that have implemented containment, treatment, and disposal measures to prevent uncontrolled environmental releases.
Law prohibits the use of intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing or training purposes.
Notes: HB 1351; Signed into law on March 10, 2021

Description: Prohibits the manufacture, sale, or distribution of new, not previously owned, juvenile products that contains PFAS at a detectable level above an unspecified amount.

Law prohibits distribution and sale of food packaging containing "regulated PFAS" beginning on Jan. 1, 2023. Certain cookware must disclose presence of PFAS in an online disclosure beginning on Jan. 1, 2023, and on product packaging beginning on Jan. 1, 2024.
Notes: AB 1200; Signed into law on Oct. 5, 2021

Description: Bill would prohibit local governments from issuing vouchers, rebates, or other financial incentives for the use of synthetic grass or artificial turf that contains PFAS.
Bill would state the intent of the legislature to enact legislation that would eliminate PFAS from menstrual products.

Bill would prohibit the manufacture, distribution, or sale of new textile articles that contain regulated PFAS, beginning Jan. 1, 2025, with some exceptions. Sets maximum textile flourine content at 100 parts per million beginning in 2025 and 50 parts per million beginnin in 2027.
Notes: AB 1817; Signed into law on Sept. 29, 2022

Description: Bill would expand existing ban on certain PFAS in cosmetics (going into effect in 2025) to apply to the entire class of PFAS.
Notes: AB 2771; Signed into law on Sept. 29, 2022

Description: Law forbids items advertised as "compostable" or "home compostable" to be sold in the state if they have a total organic flourine concentration greater than 100 parts per million. The Department of Resources Recycling and Recovery can adopt a different standard if it more effectively limits PFAS.
Notes: AB 1201; Signed into law on Oct. 5, 2021

Description: The Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment listed perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) as a carcinogen under Proposition 65.
Include treatments containing any perfluoroalkyl or polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFASs) for use on converted textiles or leathers as a Priority Product under the Safer Consumer Products Regulations.
The Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment listed perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS) and its salts and transformation and degradation precursors as a carcinogen under Proposition 65.

Prohibit class B firefighting foam from being manufactured, or knowingly sold or distributed, and prohibit a person from using in this state, class B firefighting foam to which PFAS chemicals have been intentionally added.
As part of sustainable packaging regulation, food service packaging with PFAS in excess of 100 parts per million cannot be considered recyclable.
Added 62 PFAS substances to a list of contaminants that wastewater treatment facilities must report when detected.
Notes: Ongoing emmissions reporting must begin with 2028 data reported in 2029

Description: Products or packaging with PFAS in excess of 100 parts per million or with PFAS that has a functional/technical effect in the product/packaging cannot be considered recyclable.
Notes: SB 343; Signed into law on Oct. 5, 2021

Description: Include carpets and rugs containing PFAS chemicals as a Priority Product under the Safer Consumer Products Regulations.

The Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment initiated the development of identification materials for the listing of perfluorodecanoic acid (PFDA) and its salts, perfluorohexanesulfonic acid (PFHxS) and its salts, perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA) and its salts, and perfluoroundecanoic acid (PFUnDA) and its salts as developmental and reproductive toxicants under Proposition 65.
Notes: 45-day data call in period ended May 10, 2021

Description: Proposed setting Public Health Goal levels for PFOA and PFOS in drinking water at 0.007 ppt and 1 ppt, respectively.
Notes: Bloomberg Law coverage of latest development: https://news.bloomberglaw.com/pfas-project/california-advances-on-forever-chemical-drinking-water-limits

Description: Recommendation from Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment to assign a Notification Level to PFBS in drinking water.
Notes: Bloomberg Law coverage of latest development: https://news.bloomberglaw.com/environment-and-energy/california-ponders-adding-new-forever-chemical-to-notify-list

Description: Prohibit selling, making, or delivering cosmetics that contain two dozen toxic ingredients, including PFOA, PFOS, PFDA, and PFNA.
Establishes Memorandum Accounts for four water utilities that will allow for potential recovery of PFAS-related expenses such as testing and customer notification of high PFAS levels.
Allows the State Water Resources Control Board to order multiple districts at once to test for PFAS and requires water suppliers to notify customers of PFAS.
Set drinking water notification limits of 5.1ppt for PFOA and 6.5 ppt for PFOS. Limits are non-binding but linked to future drinking water standards.
Set levels of PFOA and PFOS at which suppliers have to notify their governing boards at 5.1 ppt and 6.5 ppt respectively.

Include PFOA and PFOS as chemicals of concern under Safe Drinking Water and Toxic Enforcment Act (Proposition 65) requiring anyone doing business in the state to provide warnings if they knowingly and intentionally expose any individual to the listed substances.
California is conducting biomonitoring studies to screen for PFAS.

Expands ban on Class B firefighting foam with intentionally added PFAS. Prohibits use in certain aircraft hangars and requires certification process for facilities or fire departments using or storing PFAS in its operations.
Change to state's "Primary Drinking Water Regulations" establish PFAS as target chemicals in wastewater. The designation requires measures to reduce PFAS if present in treated wastewater.

Law bans sale and distribution of following PFAS-containing products on various timelines. Jan. 1, 2024: carpets/rugs, fabric treatments, food packaging, juvenile products, and oil/gas products. Cookware with PFAS will require disclosure after Jan. 1, 2024. Jan. 1, 2025: cosmetics, indor textile furnishings, indoor upholstered furniture. Jan. 1, 2027: outdoor textile furnishings and outdoor upholstered furniture. Also requires disclosure of PFAS firefighting foam discharges, prohibits discharges in waterways.
Notes: H 1345; Referred to as the "Perfluoroalkyl and Polyfluoroalkyl Chemicals Consumer Protection Act"; Signed into law on June 3, 2022.

Description: Policy implements and interprets narrative standard provisions in commission's PFAS regulations. Provides guidance on PFAS laboratory testing, monitoring, and cleanup.
Notes: Water Quality Control Commission Policy 20-1; Expires July 31, 2025

Description: Bill would require underground oil and gas operations to disclose chemical products, including certifying that they contain no intentionally added PFAS.

Requires all persons who store or use Class B firefighting foam containing PFAS to register and obtain a certificate from the Hazardous Materials and Waste Management Division. The regulations also require any person that uses such foams in testing firefighting foam fire systems to capture the spent foam.
Notes: Regulations are a response to 2020 legislation.

Description: Creation of a fund to identify and mitigate PFAS contamination. Fund also supports a program to purchase and dispose of products containing PFAS. The efforts are funded by a fee on trucks transporting fuel.
Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing or training purposes. Also restricts the sale of such foams.

Combined presence of PFOS and PFOA limited to 0.070 micrograms per liter for an area in the vicinity of Fountain Creek in central El Paso County. The regulation is in response to potential contamination at Peterson Air Force Base.
Lists PFOA and PFOS as hazardous constitutents in the state's hazardous waste regulations.
Bill would authorize $30 million in bonds that would fund grants to fire departments to remove PFAS from fire equipment, as well as decontaminate, renovate, and replace affected equipment.
Bill would allocate $100,000 to test shellfish for presence of PFAS.
Requires a release that contains per- or polyfluoroalkyl substances in liquid form, and includes chemicals commonly referred to as PFOS, PFOA, PFNA, PFHpA, and PFHxS must be reported.
Law requires water bottle companies in the state to sample source water and test for PFAS and other unregulted contaminants.
Law prohibits the use of PFAS in firefighting foams and establishes a take-back program for such products. The law also bans the use of PFAS in food packaging beginning no later than Dec. 31, 2023.
Allocates $1.15 million in grants to municipalities for assesment and remediation of PFAS contamination.

Adopted EPA's advisory level of 70 ppt in drinking water. That limit applies to five PFAS: PFOA, PFOS, perfluorononanoic acid (PFNA), perfluroheptanoic acid (PFHpA), and perfluorohexane sulfonic acid PFHxS).

Connecticut's Interagency PFAS Task Force drafted a PFAS action plan that lays out strategy to minimize environmental exposure to PFAS, minimize future PFAS releases, and to identify/assess/clean up historical PFAS releases.

Law requires a statewide survey on PFAS in drinking water throughout the state. It also requires the establishment of maximum contaminant levels for specific contaminants found in drinking water, including PFOA and PFOS.
Notes: HB 8; Signed into law on Oct. 20, 2021

Description: Proposed rule chance would set maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) for PFOA and PFOS at near-zero levels.

Added PFOS and PFOA to the list of hazardous substances under the state's Hazardous Substance Cleanup Act. Presence of the two chemicals individually or combined at 70 ppt could trigger further evaluation.
Appropriations act allocates a combined $32.8 million to detect and remediate PFAS in drinking water and wastewater.
Notes: HB 5001; Signed into law on June 2, 2022

Description: Law requires regulators to establish statewide PFAS cleanup target levels if the federal government hasn't finalized PFAS standards by 2025. Requires future PFAS regulations to be approved by the legislature. Suspends statute of limitations for state and local government entities seeking relief if their existing authority is limited by this bill.
Notes: HB 1475 / SB 7012; Signed into law on June 20, 2022

Description: Bill would appropriate $1 million in funds for the University of Florida PFAS Contaminated Material Treatment Pilot program.
Bill would appropriate funds for the University of Florida PFAS Contaminated Material Treatment Pilot program.
Bill would require manufacturers to disclose when restricted substances such as PFAS are in cosmetics. Beginning in 2026, those restricted substances would be banned in cosmetics.
Bill would prohibit the sale and distribution of feminine hygine products containing PFAS.
Bill would prohibit the sale of food packaging and new children's products that contain PFAS.
Bill would prohibit the distribution and use of single use carryout products containing PFAS in any public building operated by the Georgia Building Authority.

Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing or training purposes except at facilities that have implemented containment, treatment, and disposal measures to prevent uncontrolled environmental releases.
The Department of Health updated its interim PFAS Environmental Action Levels (EALs) to reflect new information from federal regulators.
Notes: Additional updates to the EALs are anticipated in 2023

Description: Bill would establish a water quality task force to address PFAS contamination in the state's drinking water.
Notes: SB 1459; Senate Committee on Water and Land recommended the measure be passed with amendments on Feb. 13, 2023

Description: Bill would ban food packaging, food service ware, cosmetics, and personal care products that contain PFAS.
Bill would in-part establish a community oversight committee to advise on remediation of leaked PFAS-containing firefighting foam at the U.S. Dept. of Defense's Red Hill Bulk Fuel Storage Facility.
Prohibits the manufacture, distribution, or sale of any food packaging that contains PFAS. Also prohibits class B firefighting foams, with certain exceptions.
Notes: H.B. 1644; Although the bill takes effect July 1, 2022, effective dates for restrictions are 1/1/2023 (fire foam manufacturer notice), 7/1/2024 (fire foam ban), and  12/31/2024 (food packaging ban).

Description: The Department of Health updated interim soil and groundwater Environmental Action Levels (EALs) for screening of sites contaminated with per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS).  The updated EALs replace action levels presented in the December 2020 technical memorandum.
Bill would require the Environmental Council to develop a tool for identifying environmental justice communities exposed to PFAS, among other things.
Proposed bill would create an environmental justice mapping task force that would in part explore pollution burdens created by PFAS contamination.
Bill would allow the state Environmental Protection Agency to create a take-back program for local fire departments that use and store older firefighting foam made with PFAS.
Bill would ban the inclusion of certain chemicals, including several PFAS, in cosmetics.
Bill would provide that the disposal by incineration of aqueous film-forming foam that contains any PFAS is prohibited.
Notes: HB 3190; Both houses of the legislatures unanimously approved the legislation but it was vetoed in full by the governor on August 24, 2021, and it did not become law.

Description: Prohibits the disposal by incineration of any perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substance.
Notes: HB 4818; Signed into law on June 8, 2022.

Description: Limits the use of Class B PFAS-containing firefighting foams for testing or training beginning Jan. 1, 2022. Prohibits the manufacture, use, and sale of such foams beginning on Jan. 1, 2025.
Proposed rule woud amend environmental laboratory provisions to incorporate by reference the EPA PFAS Drinking Water Laboratory Methods.

The Illinois EPA issued four non-enforceable statewide health advisories for PFAS in groundwater or drinking water. The level for PFOA, at 2 PPT, is the lowest in the nation. Illinois EPA will use the advisories and data from investigations to develop maximum contaminant levels.
Notes: Bloomberg Law coverage of latest development: https://news.bloomberglaw.com/pfas-project/illinois-epa-issues-health-advisories-for-four-pfas-chemicals

Description: Developing groundwater quality standards that would limit PFOA and PFOS presence to 70 ppt combined or individually.

Two state agencies launched a PFAS firefighting foam collection program to remove and properly dispose of PFAS material from any fire agency that requests it. The service is free with no additional requirements.
Notes: The program has collected more than 32,000 gallons of foam as of February 2023

Description: Bill would establish a PFAS biomonitoring pilot program to test the PFAS levels in the blood of 1,000 current and former firefighters. It would also investigate whether there are health implications with elevated PFAS levels.
Notes: HB 1219; Bill unanimously passed the House and was referred to the Senate on Feb. 14, 2023

Description: Bill would prohibit fire departments from purchasing firefighter gear unless it contains a permanently attached label that discloses whether or not the gear contains PFAS.
Notes: HB 1341; Bill unanimously passed the House and was referred to the Senate on Jan. 31, 2023

Description: Bill would require the Indiana Department of Health to establish maximum contaminant levels for PFAS in waer provided by public water systems.
Ban on firefighting foams that contain PFAS chemicals in training.
Set screening levels for concentration of three PFAS compounds in accordance with EPA's health advisory of 70 ppt.
Bill would require inspection of a private well serving a building upon transfer of ownership of the building. The test would include screening for PFAS.
Bill would wastewater plants to test for the presence of PFAS.
Issued a PFAS Action Plan to identify and minimize exposure, prevent future releases, and provide education, outreach and communication.
Planning to test for PFOA and PFOS contamination in drinking water using EPA health advisory of 70 ppt.
Bill would require regulators to establish PFAS maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) and monitoring requirements.

Bill would require the Energy and Environment Cabinet to promulgate regulations establishing maximum PFAS chemical limits and monitoring requirements for public drinking water and maximum PFAS limits and monitoring requirements for discharges.
Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would address PFAS in packaging waste.
Restrictions on use of firefighting foams that contain PFAS chemicals in training or testing.

Law prohibits the use of PFAS-containing Class B firefighting foam outside of fire prevention or an emergency fire fighting operation. The manufacture, sale, and distribution of PFAS-containing firefighting foam is still permitted.
Notes: HB 389; Signed into law on June 11, 2021

Description: Draft bill would create a program to assist farmers affected by PFAS contamination by remediating contamination, including by growing alternative crops.
Bill would require bottled water companies that extract water in the state to monitor for PFAS and implement treatment if PFAS is detected at or above applicable standards.
Bill would set maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) for six types of PFAS at zero nanograms per liter.
Bill would require health insurance carriers to provide coverage to test blood for the presence of PFAS.

Bill would change regulators' ability to create PFAS-related rules so that new rules are considered "major substantive rules" subject to provisional adoption by the legislature rather than "routine technical rules" that are finalized at the end of the rulemaking process.

Draft bill would revise the definition of PFAS to align with federal law, require downstream notification and allow for a safe harbor, implement a process for banning harmful chemicals that include exemptions for de minimis concentrations and replacement parts, require the consideration of limiting access to areas contaminated by PFAS and prohibit certain bulk chemicals, components and parts containing PFAS.
Bill would amend waste discharge licensing laws so that when that Department of Environmental Protection requires wastewater sampling and PFAS testing, the department covers the costs.
Draft bill will include language to require the development and implementation of a program to support manufacturers whose products contain PFAS.
Bill would require the state to offer to purchase land on commercial farms that were contaminated with PFAS prior to Jan. 1, 2023.
Bill introduced relating to PFAS that doesn't include any details because the draft language is still being worked on.
Draft bill will include language to establish statewide PFAS testing standards and set acceptable levels for PFAS. Full text is not yet available.
Supplemental appropriations act contains several PFAS expenditures.
Law requires screening for PFAS in sludge or sludge-derived compost that is applied to land.
Rulemaking to implement HP 185 requires disclosure of PFAS in pesticides.

Amends ban on PFAS in firefighting foam to exempt marine defense applications or uses required by U.S. Department of Defense. Also adds new requirement for manufacturers to supply certification that their foam doesn't contain PFAS or is exempt from PFAS prohibition.
Notes: HP 1502; Signed by governor on April 7, 2022.

Description: Bill would ban the distribution of pesticides containing PFAS.
Bill would establish a $100 million fund to assist people whose agricultural land was contaminated by PFAS.
Law requires manufactuers to provide notification if any personal, residential, commercial, or industrial product contains PFAS. Also prohibits the sale of new rugs or carpets containing PFAS.
Notes: HP 1113; Passed by the House and Senate on July 2, 2021. Became law without governor's signature on July 15, 2021.

Description: Bill would require state-owned solid waste disposal facilities to establish leachate treatment to reduce PFAS.

Bans the use of PFAS-containing firefighting foam for testing or training purposes unless proper disposal measures are in place. The manufacture and sale of such foam is also prohibited (except at oil terminals where the restriction goes into effect Jan. 1, 2025). Discharges of PFAS-containing foam near water supplies must be reported within 24 hours.
Notes: HP 1115; Signed into law on July 9, 2021

Description: Establishes fund to test and monitor for presence of PFAS in soil and groundwater. The fund is financed by a new $10 per ton disposal fee on septage, industrial sludge, and other residual.
Notes: HP 1189; Passed by the House and Senate on July 2, 2021. Became law without governor's signature on July 15, 2021.

Description: Law establishes a statute of limitations on civil actions arising from harm or injury from PFAS.
Notes: HP 261; Signed into law on June 22, 2021

Description: Appropriations measure includes funding to treat drinking water conatminated with PFAS and mitigate PFAS in drinking water at schools and daycares.
Notes: SP 577; Signed into law on July 19, 2021

Description: Bill would authorize issuance of a general fund bond that would help pay for hazardous substance cleanup, including at uncontrolled sites polluted with PFAS.
Notes: HP 106; In July 2021, the legislature announced the bill would be carried over to the next session.

Description: Appropriations measure includes several allocations for PFAS mitigation, research, and financial assistance.
Notes: HP 156; Signed into law on July 1, 2021

Description: Law directs regulators to establish maximum contaminant levels for PFAS. The law creates an interim limit of 20 ppt for the presence of six PFAS in drinking water: PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFNA, PFHpA, and PFDA. Monitoring standards are also established.
Notes: SP 64; Final rule establishing MCLs due by June 1, 2024; Bloomberg Law coverage of latest development: https://news.bloomberglaw.com/pfas-project/maine-joins-states-setting-pfas-drinking-water-limits-before-epa

Description: Law requires manufacturer disclosure when registered pesticides contain PFAS. It also directs regulators to study "if fluorinated adjuvants are being used or sold in the State."
Notes: HP 185; Signed into law on June 21, 2021. An initial version of the bill would have banned the aerial application of pesticides.

Description: Law directs state regulators to develop a comprehensive plan to identify and aid farmers affected by PFAS. A final report with findings and recommendations is due to the legislature by Feb. 1, 2022.
Notes: HP 403; Signed into law on June 10, 2021

Description: Requires companies making children's toys containing any of five PFAS substances to alert the state's Department of Environmental Protection.
Notes: Bloomberg Law coverage of latest development: https://news.bloomberglaw.com/pfas-project/maine-requires-notice-on-kids-products-made-with-five-pfas

Description: Amendments to law on toxic materials in packaging gives the state the authority to ban the sale of food packaging contianing PFAS if a safer alternative is available.
Requirement to test sludge/biosolids for PFOS, PFOA, and PFBS.

Governor executive order creating a task force to review PFAS contamination. The task force drafted a response plan released in November 2019 with recommendations for testing and product restrictions.
Set action levels for presence of PFOS in milk.
Proposed bill would require PFAS monitoring and reporting at publicly owned treatment facilities.
Notes: SB 225 / HB 499; Bill was withdrawn on Feb. 13, 2023

Description: Bill would prohibit products or packaging from being considered recylable if they're made with PFAS.
Bill would prohibit mosquito pesticides from being registered in the state unless they pass a test showing levels of PFAS below a certain threshold.

Law bans the use, manufacture, or sale of Class B firefighting foam; rugs or carpets; and food packaging designed for direct food contact, if any contain intentionally added PFAS. Implements foam containment measures, requires disclosure of foam use, establishes take-back program for firefighting foam, and forbids foam from being incinerated or placed in a landfill. Manufacturers must disclose if firefighter protective equipment contains PFAS.
Notes: HB 275 / SB 273; Signed into law on April 21, 2022.

Description: Bill would prohibit certain ingredients in cosmetics, including PFOA and PFOS.
Notes: HB 643; became law without governor's signature.

Description: Enacts legislation to prohibit the use of Class B firefighting foam that contain intentionally added PFAS chemicals for certain testing or training purposes.
Bill would prohibit products or packaging from being considered recylable if they're made with PFAS.
Two state agencies launched a PFAS firefighting foam collection program in 2018 to collect and destroy legacy AFFF.
Notes: The program has collected more than 203,000 pounds (or more than 23,000 gallons) of firefighting foam as of February 2023.

Description: Bill would require the Department of Environmental Protection to outline best practices and recommended regulations for proper disposal of products containing PFAS. It would also require a study of PFAS sites and response plan strategies.

Bill would indemnify farmers from claims resulting from PFAS in soil, water, or agricultural products as a result of standard agricultural practices. It would also set up a relief fund for farmers suffering loss or costs due to PFAS contamination and waive conveyance taxes for land removed from agricultural or horticultural use due to regulatory action over PFAS. Bill also would require testing biosolids for PFAS and set maximum levels of PFAS for fertilizers and compost.
Bill would require written notice and explanation of PFAS in firefighter gear beginning in 2025. A full ban on PFAS in firefighting gear would go into effect in 2027.
Bill would ban the sale of children's products containing intentionally added PFAS or containing flourine levels above 100 parts per million (ppm).
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of packaging that contains PFAS.
Bill would ban the sale of beverage containers, food ware, and food containers that contain PFAS.
Bill would prohibit items from being classified as recyclable if they contain toxic substances such as PFAS.
Bill would ban food packaging with intentionally added PFAS.
Bill would require written notice and explanation of PFAS in firefighter gear beginning in 2025. A full ban on PFAS in firefighting gear would go into effect in 2027.
Bill would ban the sale of children's products containing PFAS.
Bill would establish a program to issue PFAS home filtration equipment.

Bill would establish a PFAS Remediation Trust Fund to mitigate impacts of PFAS contamination. It would also ban intentionally added PFAS in food packaging, and a variety of products including cookware, fabric treatements, personal care products, rugs, carpets, and children's products. Additionally, establishes a registry of PFAS-containing products, as well as a PFAS awareness campaign. Also bans the use of PFAS in firefighting protective equipment.
Bill introduced relating to PFAS that doesn't include any details because the draft language is still being worked on.

Bill would establish a PFAS Research and Development Public Safety Fund to suport development, testing, and purchase of a PFAS-free moisture barrier that meets NFPA requirements for inclusion in firefighter turnout gear.
Bill would require an outside research organization to study the effect of PFAS on agricultural products and other food.
Appropriations bill includes $100,000 to test and remediate PFAS in town of Princeton.
Notes: H 5050; Signed into law on Aug. 2, 2022

Description: Appropriations bill revives a previously established interagency task force investigating PFAS contamination. The task force is continued until June 30, 2022, when a report on its findings is due.
Covid-19 appropriations act used federal funds to provide $2.15 million for PFAS remediation in two communities.
Supplemental appropriations law provides multiple allocations for PFAS remediation.
Notes: H 5374; Passed by the legislature Nov. 3, 2022

Description: Infrastructure spending bill includes $1.2 million for various towns' projects to remediate PFAS in drinking water.
The PFAS Interagency Task Force released its final report with suggested actions the commonwealth can take to protect public health and the environment.
Notes: Recommendations included funding for PFAS detection/remediation, phasing out PFAS in consumer products, expanding regulations, and more support for firefighters.

Description: Interagency task force created to review and investigate water and soil contamination of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances across the commonwealth. Report on findings due to the legislature by Dec. 31, 2021.
Notes: H 5164; See Section 98 of the Act; Final report submitted on April 20, 2022.

Description: All PFAS substances with a "perfluoroalkyl moiety with three or more carbons" or a "perfluoroalkylether moiety with two or more carbons" are added to the state's Toxic or Hazardous Substance List under a new category of "PFAS Not Otherwise Listed." Companies in Massachusetts that make or use large amounts of certain PFAS must track and report that work.
Notes: Adopted Dec. 7, 2021, to take effect Jan. 1, 2022. Usage report for 2022 due July 1, 2023.

Description: Requires all public drinking water systems to regularly test for six PFAS substances and set a maximum containment level of 20 ppt. Replacement or remediation of water would be required at or above that threshold.
Supplemental appropriation of $4.2 million for testing and treatment of PFAS contamination in drinking water.

Added a new certification category to laboratories to analyze drinking water for Per-and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS), and specified the approved methods that certified laboratories must use for PFAS analysis in drinking water.

Added PFDA, PFHpA, PFHxS, PFOA, PFOS, and PFNA to state's list of toxic chemicals that must be tested for in groundwater or soil near contaminated sites. Remediation required if PFAS substances found alone or in combination at 20 ppt or greater.
$24 million earmarked in state supplemental funding bill for municipalities to test and remediate drinking water.

Appropriations law allocated $15 million for PFAS remediation at a former industrial site. The law also calls for at least $18 million of the Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy's budget to provide drinking water assistance to remove or reduce PFAS.
Notes: SB 565; Signed into law on March 30, 2022

Description: Rule implements law banning PFAS-containing firefighting foam for testing or training. It also establishes best practices/mandatory reporting procedures when such foam is discharged per previously passed law.
Added existing limits on PFAS in public drinking water supplies to groundwater celan-up rules.
Established PFAS cleanup standards that align with maximum contaminant levels for PFNA, PFHxA, PFHxS, PFBS, and HFPO-DA (also known as GenX).
Established maximum contaminant levels for PFNA, PFOA, PFHxA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFBS, and HFPO-DA (also known as GenX).
Disposed of 51,404 gallons of PFAS-containing fire foam through a collection program that ended July 30, 2020.
Directs state agency to create rules for firefighters' use of PFAS-containing firefighting foam.

Requires firefighters to report the use of firefighting foam containing intentionally added PFAS. Also requires the Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy to establish a collection program for firefighting foam concentrate.
Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in firefighting foam used for testing or training purposes.
Established a PFAS Action Response Team to research, identify, recommend, and implement response to PFAS conamination.
Drinking water limit for PFOA and PFOS of 70 ppt, mirroring EPA health advisory level.
Bill would ban PFAS in packaging for cannabis flower, cannabinoid products, and hemp-derived consumer products.
Bill would prohibit the registration of pesticides containing PFAS.
Bill would require regulators to adopt water quality standards for PFOA and PFOS, as well as set the health risk limit for PFOS at 0.015 parts per billion (ppb).
Bill would require disclosure to the Pollution Control Agency of products containing intentionally added PFAS, as well as the amount of PFAS and its purpose.

Bill would require notification when a product contains intentionally added PFAS. It would also ban the sale of a wide variety of consumer products containing intentionally added PFAS, including childrens' products and cookware. A full ban on the sale of all consumer products containing intentionally added PFAS would go into effect in 2030.
Bill would prohibit packaging for cannabis and hemp-derived consumer products from containing or being coated with perfluoroalkyl substances.
Bill would ban manufacture, sale, and distribution of PFAS-containing Class B firefighting foam. This would expand an existing ban on discharge of such foam for training or testing.

Proposed rule would, among other things, add a new Class 1 WQS for emerging pollutants of concern, including per-and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), and potentially pesticides, pharmaceuticals, algal toxins, disinfection by-products, and/or additional industrial chemicals.
Ban on the use of PFAS in food packaging. The law also includes more than $2.5 million in funding for PFAS-related expenditures such as research and remediation.
Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing or training purposes.
Established maximum levels of PFBS, PFHxS, PFOS, PFBA, and PFOA in drinking water that could lead to state action.
FY 2022 Intended Use Plan for the state's Water Pollution Control Revolving Loan Fund Program allocates approximately $4 billion for remediation of emerging contaminants "with a focus on PFAS/PFOA."
Notes: $4 billion allocation takes place from 2022-2026 with $800,000 being allocated annually.

Description: Classified PFOS and PFOA as a "toxic" pollutant in drinking water that triggers a health advisory when present at the EPA health advisory level of 70 ppt.
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of certain PFAS-containing products. It would also require the disclosure of intentionally added PFAS in cookware.

Requires the State Environmental Commission to establish water quality standards, effluent limitations and maximum permissible levels in public water systems for PFAS. Also requires a permit to store or dispose of PFAS, and prohibits, with certain exceptions, the use, manufacture, or sale of certain Class B firefighting foams for training/testing.
Notes: AB 97; portions of the law take effect July 1, 2022.

Description: Bill would require installers of new well pumps to test for PFAS and notify property buyers of presence of PFAS before executing a contract.

Bill would add duties to the Department of Environmental Services that require it to investigate, test, and monitor for PFAS. It would also change the name of the PFAS Loan Fund to the PFAS Response Fund, as well as appropriate $2 million to that fund.
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of food packaging containing PFAS.
Bill would require health insurance coverage for preventative PFAS care when individuals have elevated levels of PFAS in their blood.
Bill would require disclosure of PFAS or other groundwater contamination prior to the sale of real estate.
Bill would restrict the use of PFAS in rugs, carpets, and aftermarket stain and water resistant treatments.

Bill would require the Department of Health and Human Services to develop a health outcomes repository to collect information relative to adverse human health effects in areas impacted by PFAS air emissions and contaminated drinking water. The repository will collect adverse health outcome information.
Bill would require regulators to commence rulemaking on ways to control toxic materials such as PFAS that are processed in advanced recyling facilities.
Bill would collectively allocate $10 million across two years to the PFAS remediation loan fund (which helps with remediation of PFAS contamination).
Bill would establish a common law claim for recovery of costs associated with medical monitoring following significant exposure to PFAS.

Interim rule expands criteria and procedures for administering the PFAS Remediation Loan Fund program to assist public water systems and municipalities with the cost of complying with maximum contaminant levels.
Notes: Interim rule in response to enactment of HB 271. Expires April 28, 2022. A proposal to extend the rule past expiration is pending.

Description: Bill would require adoption of groundwater quality standards for perfluorobutanoic acid (PFBA), perfluoroheptanoic acid (PFHpA), and perfluorodecanoic acid (PFDA).
Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would require testing for PFAS in drinking water at child care facilities and schools.

Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would add PFBA and PFBS to a list of PFAS with maximum contaminant levels (MCLs). It would also set a cumulative total of 20 parts per trillion (ppt) for all PFAS MCLs.
Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would, among other things, ban the sale of carpets that contain or are treated with PFAS, or any fabric treatment containing PFAS.
Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would requre PFAS warning labels on consumer products.
Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would establish a rulemaking schedule for surface water quality standards for perfluorinated chemicals.

Prefiled bill for the 2022 session would require landfills sited within a proscribed distance of groundwater sources to monitor for the presence of all of the EPA Priority Pollutants and four PFAS listed by the state.
Requires bottled water manufacturers to test for PFAS contaminants and submit results when submitting or renewing beverage licenses.
Adjusts criteria for the PFAS remediation grants and loans.

Sets maximum contaminant levels for PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, and PFNA. Establishes a per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances fund and programs and makes appropriations. Extends the commission on the seacoast cancer cluster investigation.
Notes: HB 1264; Signed into law on July 28, 2020. The law has varying effective dates for its different components. The new MCLs for the PFAS substances go into effect June 30, 2022. HB 271 (signed Aug. 24, 2021) makes various technical amendments.

Description: Establishes a statute of limitations on civil actions arising from harm or injury from PFAS.
Set enforceable standard for PFOA or PFOS found alone and combined at 70 ppt for drinking water, groundwater, and cleanups.
Notes: This regulation will be superceded by HB 1264 when it goes into effect.

Description: Set stricter limits for PFOA, PFOS, PFNA, and PFHxS chemicals in drinking water. A November 2019 injunction as part of a 3M lawsuit suspended implementation of the legislation.
Notes: The injunction is now moot due to passage of HB 1264 that codified these limits through the legislative process. More info on injunction: https://news.bloomberglaw.com/environment-and-energy/new-hampshire-judge-suspends-states-new-pfas-restrictions.

Description: Establishes criteria and procedures for administering the PFAS Remediation Loan Fund program to assist public water systems with the cost of complying with maximum contaminant levels.
Bill would establish standards for claims for medical monitoring damages following exposure to PFAS.
Requires regular reporting of PFAS testing results to the New Hampshire legislature.
Ban on firefighting foam that contians PFAS chemicals.
Established commission to investigate the environmental and public health impacts from air, soil, and groundwater PFAS releases in three towns.
Establishes standards for monitoring for the presence of PFAS in water systems.
The Department of Environmental Protection held a take back and disposal program for PFAS-containing firefighting foam in 2020.
Notes: The DEP coordinated and funded the collection of approximately 18,000 gallons of AFFF from more than 140 municipal fire companies.

Description: Bill would require regulators to study using alternate water supplies when PFAS exceeds maximum contaminant level.
Interim soil remediation standards established for PFNA, PFOA, PFOS, and GenX.
Bill would require water systems and landlords to provide notice of elevated PFAS levels in drinking water, as well as require regulators to set up an educational program.
Bill would require regulators to perform an annual assessment of unregulated PFAS to determine if maximum contaminant levels are necessary.

Bill would prohibit PFAS from being intentionally added to certain products (including cosmetics, carpets, food packaging, and cookware), require notification of PFAS in products, and establish educational programming and research.
Notes: S 3177 / A 4758; titled the "Protecting Against Forever Chemicals Act"

Description: Bill would require public community water systems to identify alternative water source if PFAS exceeds maximum contaminant levels in existing sources.
Bill would require regulators to perform a study on regulating PFAS in drinking water and possible treatment methods.
Bill would prohibit the sale, manufacture, distribution, and use of firefighting foam with intentionally added PFAS.
Set interim specific groundwater quality standards for chloroperfluoropolyether carboxylates (ClPFPECAs) at 0.002 micrograms per liter.
Notes: The Department will replace the interim standard with a specific criterion as soon as reasonably possible through rulemaking.

Description: Bill would restrict discharge of firefighting foams containing perfluoroalkyl or polyfluoroalkyl substances for training or testing purposes.
Proposed bill would prohibit products containing PFAS from being classified as recyclable.
Notes: S 2145 / A 1554; Re-introduced after failing to advance in 2021 legislature

Description: Maximum contaminant levels of 14 ppt for PFOA, 14 ppt for PFNA, and 13 ppt for PFOS in drinking water.
Ordered five manufacturers to conduct an assessment of their PFAS use and discharge. The directive also set up a fund to remediate damages.
Set interim specific groundwater quality standards for PFOA and PFOS at 10 ppt.
Bill would explicitly allow the state's Office of Natural Resources Trustee to pursue natural resources injury claims for PFAS releases.
Added PFOA and PFOS to the state's list of toxic pollutants where they're regulated at a risk-based level of 70 ppt.
Bill would, among other things, ban the sale of carpets that contain or are treated with PFAS.
Notes: SB 5027; Signed into law on Dec. 28, 2022

Description: Bill would prohibit the use of perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances in common apparel.
Notes: AB 7063 / SB 6291; Signed into law on Dec. 30, 2022

Description: Bill would push back the state's ban on carpets containing or treated with PFAS. The ban would take effect in Dec. 31, 2026 rather than Dec. 31, 2024.
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of anti-fogging sprays and wipes that contain PFAS.
Bill would ban the sale, manufacture, and distribution of packaging material containing PFAS above the practical quantification limit.
Bill would cap the real estate taxes that the city of Newburgh pays due to the construction of a granular activated carbon treatment facility meant to eliminate PFAS in the water supply.

Bill would ban the sale of new apparel containing intentionally added PFAS. It would also eventually ban the sale of apparel with PFAS above a certain limit and outdoor apparel for severe wet conditions.
Bill would require publicly owned treatment works and people who discharge industrial waste to treatment works to disclose PFAS measurements.
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of packaging containing PFAS.
Bill would require written notification of intentionally added PFAS in products and phase out the sale of those products.
Bill would prohibit intentionally added PFAS in personal care and cosmetic products and require limits on PFAS byproducts/contaminants in those items.
Bill would ban the presence of PFAS in menstrual products.
Ban on use of PFAS substances in food packaging.
Notes: S 8817 / A 4739; Signed into law on Dec. 2, 2020

Description: Revives statute of limitations to give water providers additional 18 months to sue polluters for liability claims over emerging contaminants (including several PFAS substances) that otherwise would have barred.
Proposed rule would add maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) for four PFAS substances (PFDA, PFHpA, PFHxS, and PFNA) and add 19 additional PFAS substances to the state's list of emerging contaminants.
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of anti-fogging sprays and wipes that contain PFAS.

Creates initial list of PFAS substances that are "emerging contaminants." Water utilities must regularly test for these substances. Formalized regulations must be written within 90 days of bill signing and the list of "emerging contaminants" must be updated every three years.
Requires manufacturers to report presence of non-essential PFAS in products to state regulators by 2024. Bans the use of non-essential PFAS by 2025.
Bill would prohibit the sale of any cosmetic product or personal care product containing PFAS.
Capital projects budget bill would, among other things, appropriate funding for the State University of New York at Stony Brook to provide for a new laboratory testing facility for PFOA.
Bill would regulate the use of chemicals including PFAS as an ingredient in consumer products.
Bill would establish maximum contaminant levels in drinking water for perfluoroalkyl carboxylic acids and perfluoroalkyl sulfonic acids.
Prohibits the incineration of firefighting foam containing PFAS substances in the small upstate community of Cohoes, N.Y., where an incinerator is located.
Notes: AB 9952; Bloomberg Law Story; Signed into law on Nov. 23, 2020

Description: Maximum contaminant levels in drinking water of 10 ppt for PFOA and PFOS. Requires water systems to test for the contaminants and initiate clean up if detected beyond limits.
Notes: The listing of MCLs in New York states violations of PFOA and PFAS maximum contaminant levels may be deferred up to 24 months after they went into effect (August 2022).

Description: Places restrictions on the sale and use of firefighting equipment containing PFAS chemicals to reduce the use of PFAS chemicals in firefighting activities.
Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing training purposes. Also phases out the manufacture and sale of such foams in the state.
Requires manufacturers of children's products to comply with reporting requirements when products contain PFOA or PFOS.
Implemented emergency rule regulating PFOA and PFOS as hazardous substances. Proper storage of those compounds is required and releases to the environment are limited.
Disposed of 25,000 gallons of firefighting foam with PFAS chemicals as of summer 2018.
Notes: The Intercept reported that the department did not provide specifics on how the 25,000 gallons were "properly disposed": https://theintercept.com/2019/01/27/toxic-firefighting-foam-pfas-pfoa/

Description: Created Water Quality Response Team to investigate possible water contamination reports in New York.

Bill would authorize establishment of maximum contaminant levels for PFAS compounds. It would also establish permissible concentration levels of at least 10 parts per trillion (ppt) for individual PFAS and 70 ppt for combined PFAS. Those limits would apply to PFAS in public water systems.
Bill would establish a fund to provide financial support to fire departments replacing stocks of Class B firefighting foam that contain PFAS.
Bill would in part ban the manufacture, distribution, and sale of packaging containing PFAS.
Bill would allow the use of the Bernard Allen Memorial Emergency Drinking Water Fund to provide alternative sources of drinking water to residents living where PFAS is present in drinking water.
Bill would allow the use of the Bernard Allen Memorial Emergency Drinking Water Fund to provide alternative sources of drinking water to residents living where PFAS is present in drinking water.
Bill would ban the manufacture, distribution, and use of PFAS in the state.
Bill would require facilities holding water pollution control permits to eliminate PFAS from received wastewater prior to discharge.
Bill would require the Department of Health and Human Services to study the extent of human exposure to PFAS in the Cape Fear Basin, and issue a report by Dec. 31, 2022.
Bill would require the establishment of maximum contaminant levels for PFAS and other chemicals in drinking water.
Bill would ban the manufacture, distribution, and use of PFAS in the state.
Bill would allocate $15 million to the University of North Carolina to research PFAS (including GenX) and study filtration technologies.
Bill would hold persons who have discharged PFAS resulting in the contamination of drinking water liable for response costs for cleanup.
Bill would require the establishment of maximum contaminant levels for PFAS in drinking water.

Bill would establish a PFAS Task Force to undertake a comprehensive, nontargeted, scientific identification and analysis of PFAS present in the Lower Cape Fear Basin, and issue a report by March 1, 2022.

Proposed rule would add a groundwater quality standard for three substances (2,6-dinitrotoluene, strontium, and total PFOA and PFOS) without established interim maximum allowable concentrations. The standard for total PFOA/PFOS would be 0.07 micrograms/liter.
Requires Chemours to conduct toxicity study on chemical discharges.
Requires researchers to create inventory of aqueous film-forming foam (AFFF) used or stored by local fire departments. A final report with results due to state legislature by Oct. 15, 2020.

Requires researchers to conduct analysis for PFAS, including GenX, at surface water intakes and public water supply wells. A report on chemicals found present is due to the state legislature by Oct. 15, 2020.
Requires any person responsible for discharge of PFAS, including GenX, that results in contamination of a private drinking water well to establish permanent replacement water supplies.
Allocated $435,000 to monitor and treat presence of GenX in the Cape Fear River.
Set provisional health goal of 140 ppt for presence of GenX in drinking water.
Conducting tests to determine prevalence of PFOA and PFOS in the environment.
Updates "Water Well Standards" to require testing for presence of six PFAS substances in newly built public water system wells.
Law bans use of PFAS-containing firefighting foams in training.
Notes: HB 158; Signed into law on March 14, 2022.

Description: Bill would require the adoption of rules establishing maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) for PFAS.
Testing all 1,500 public water systems for presence of six PFAS and will notify residents about exposure risks. State also released a PFAS drinking water action plan.

Bill would require disclosure on use of biosolids (including PFAS) in products for sale and distribution. Disclosure requirements would also apply to agricultural crops or vegetables grown at a location were biosolids were applied. People and businesses using biosolids must place signage indicating as such on the property and disclose use in a sale or lease of the property.
Bill would ban the sale, manufacture, and distribution of cosmetics products containing PFAS above the practical quantification limit.
Bill would ban the sale and distribution of foodware containers containing PFAS.
Bill would require a study of PFAS in biosolids that are applied to agriculture fields in the state.
Bill would, among other things, ban the sale of carpets that contain or are treated with PFAS.
Bill would prohibit the sale or distribution of food service ware containing PFAS.

Requires manufacturers of children's products to comply with reporting requirements of the state's Toxic-Free Kids Act when products contain PFOS. The companies must eventually remove or replace the substance in certain products.
Follows EPA health guidance of 70 ppt for PFOA and PFOS.
Rule establishes maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) of 14 ppt for PFOA and 18 ppt for PFOS. The rule also establishes maximum contaminant level goals (MCLGs) for PFOA and PFOS.
Notes: Regulation #7-569; Monitoring requirements go into effect Jan. 1, 2024, or Jan. 1, 2025, depending on the size of the water system.

Description: Bill would prohibit use of PFAS-containing firefighting foam by the state or cities for testing or training purposes unless certain conditions are met. Bill also requires firefighting personal protective equipment to have warning labels if it contains intentionally added PFAS.
Bill would ban the manufacture, distribution, and sale of PFAS-containing food packaging beginning on Jan. 1, 2024.
Establishes medium-specific concentrations for PFOA, PFOS, and PFBS in soil and groundwater.
Bill would prohibit PFAS in food packaging and set penalties for violations.
Released complete and final list of PFAS levels in the state's water systems. The state said results do not indicate widespread contamination.
Notes: Study was undertaken as part of the governor's 2018 executive order establishing a PFAS Action Team.

Description: Bill would require the establishment of maximum contaminant levels for PFAS in drinking water, while also setting an interim MCL of 10 parts per trillion.

Bill would add PFAS to the definition of "hazardous substance" for the purpose of environmental cleanup. Would allow the governor to declare an emergency for communities that have PFAS-impaired drinking water systems. Would provide municipalities with immunity from liability for PFAS contamination in drinking water or wastewater discharge.
Bill would prohibit the use of class B firefighting foams containing PFAS under specified circumstances.
Bill would require the establishment of maximum contaminant levels for PFAS in drinking water.
Redirects state funds to pay for the removal of PFAS from drinking water near closed military bases.
Notes: The law has led to about $2.6 million in reimbursements paid to families for installing water filtration systems or buying bottled water as of September 2020, according to a local news report.

Description: Created PFAS Action Team to ensure safe drinking water and manage PFAS contamination.
Notes: PFAS Action Team established by governor's executive order: https://www.governor.pa.gov/newsroom/executive-order-2018-08-perfluoroalkyl-and-polyfluoroalkyl-substances-pfas-action-team/.

Description: Tested approximately 360 public water system sources for PFAS contamination.
Notes: Testing began on June 18, 2019 and the results from the first 96 test sites were published in October 2019: https://aboutblaw.com/Q8I.

Description: The Department of Environmental Management held a PFAS firefighting foam takeback program in December 2019 that collected AFFF for proper incineration.
Notes: The one-day event collected 18,000 pounds of AFFF from eight fire departments.

Description: Bill would create nine-member legislative commission to study and provide recommendations on PFAS in firefighter gear due by Jan. 1, 2024.

Requires public water utilities to regularly monitor for six PFAS: PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFNA, PFHpA, and PFDA. PFAS levels in drinking water are capped at 20 parts per trillion (ppt) beginning in July 2023. Requires establishment of PFAS levels for groundwater and surface water, landfill monitoring, investigation of PFAS contamination, and evaluation of treating PFAS as a class.
Notes: S 2298; Referred to as "The PFAS in Drinking Water, Groundwater and Surface Waters Act"; governor signed June 27, 2022. Also signed companion bill H 7233.

Description: Bill provides that no food package to which PFAS have been intentionally introduced during manufacturing or distribution in any amount can be offered for sale.
Bill would establish a task force to study PFAS in firefighting gear with findings due no later than July 1, 2024.
Bill would (with limited exceptions) ban the use of PFAS in carpets, upholstered furniture, textile furnishings, apparel, cosmetics, juvenile products, cookware and firefighting foam.
Notes: S 2449; Referred to as the "Comprehensive PFAS Ban Act of 2022"; Committee recommended bill be held for further study on March 9, 2022.

Description: Bill would include PFAS in the definition of "hazardous substances" for purposes of industrial property remediation and reuse.
Notes: S 2447; Committee recommended bill be held for further study on March 9, 2022.

Description: Bill would prohibit the use of firefighting foam containing PFAS during training exercises or testing purposes (unless mandated by law).
Updated rules governing wastewater facilities allow the Narragansett Bay Commission to require monitoring of emerging contaminants including PFAS.

Updated solid waste regulations to allow environmental regulators to require solid waste landfills to monitor groundwater for PFAS substances. Mitigation strategy required if excess amounts of PFAS are detected.
Rhode Island Department of Health declined to regulate PFAS through rulemaking due to lack of data.
Groundwater quality standard for presence of PFOS and PFOA found individually or in combination at 0.07 micrograms per liter (70 ppt).
Sampled 35 public drinking water systems and found one system with PFOA and PFAS above EPA advisory level of 70 ppt.
Proposed bill would require regulators to establish maximum contaminant levels in drinking water for PFOS, PFOA, and other PFAS compounds.
Proposed joint resolution would require regulators to establish maximum contaminant levels in drinking water for PFOS, PFOA, and other PFAS compounds.

Appropriations law allocates $10 million to PFAS remediation fund. Of that funding, 60% is earmarked for private well owners and small water systems serving fewer than 30,000 people. The remaining 40% is for water systems serving 30,000 or more customers.
Notes: HR 5150; Signed into law on June 22, 2022.

Description: The Department of Health and Environmental Control proposed to amend regulations (R.61-9) to specify requirements for analysis, monitoring, recordkeeping, and reporting related to PFAS in sludge and effluent intended for land application.
Proposed legislation would require regulators to develop maximum contaminant levels for PFOS, PFOA, and other PFAS compounds.
Released strategy to assess impact of PFAS on drinking water.
Bill would prohibit the sale and distribution of any packaging that contains PFAS beginning on July 1, 2028.
Established workgroup to identify sites with potential for contamination that will drive future monitoring efforts.
Cleanup standards for 16 PFAS chemicals at contaminated sites where protective concentration levles are exceeded.

A workgroup assembled by the Department of Environmental Quality in October 2018 developed a monitoring reconaissance plan for PFAS. The workgroup developed an ongoing monitoring and reporting strategy for PFAS contaminants.
Notes: The state's environmental regulator said on its website that "the current information doesn’t indicate that widespread PFAS contamination is likely in the state."

Description: Bill would require the development of a committee to study PFAS in leachate from landfills in the state.
Two state agencies are partnering to collect and dispose of PFAS-containing firefighting foam from fire departments.
Bill would gradually phase out the sale, manufacturing, and distribution of all products containing PFAS by 2030.

Bill would prevent consumer products being labeled as "compostable" if they contain an organic fluorine concentration greater than 100 parts per million (ppm). Regulators can establish more strict PFAS concentration limits through rulemaking.

Impose restrictions on the use, manufacture, sale, and distribution of class B firefighting foam containing perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances and impose restrictions on the manufacture, sale, and distribution of food packaging and carpets with PFAS. Also requires warning when firefighting gear contains PFAS. Designates PFHxS, PFHpA, and PFNA as chemicals of high concern to children.
Effective Date: 7/1/2022 (firefighting foam ban and chemicals of concern); 7/1/2023 (other provisions)
Notes: S 20; Signed into law on May 18, 2021. The restrictions are phased in over two years.

Description: Law requires regulators to study the prevalence of PFAS in food waste and packaging. Bill also directs consideration of rules for food waste management facilities, including PFAS standards.
Notes: HB 446; Signed into law on June 2, 2022.

Description: Appropriations law allocates $420,000 for purchase of lab equipment to test for PFAS in drinking water.
Notes: HB 740; Signed into law on June 9, 2022

Description: Requires PFAS monitoring for sludges, land applied biosolids (class B) and septage, and exceptional quality (class A) biosolids. Requires that a producer of exceptional quality biosolids disclose the presence of PFAS.

Adopts maximum contaminant level (MCL) of 20 parts per trillion for PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFHpA, and PFNA (or any combination of those substances) for drinking water. Establishes public water supply sampling requirements, sample analysis requirements, and MCL compliance standards for the five substances.
Appropriates $550,000 for engineering and construction grants to public water systems with confirmed concentrations of PFAS.

Requires regular testing of water systems for PFAS above the 20 ppt limit. Any water system above that level must provide clean water and issue a "do not drink" advisory. The law also requires a timline for developing new mandatory PFAS guidelines and establishing plan for investigating PFAS sources.
Established procedures and requirements for conducting investigations and corrective actions at PFAS release sites.
Set groundwater enforcement standard of 0.02 micrograms/liter and a preventative action level of 0.002 micrograms/liter for any combination of PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFHpA, and PFNA.
Established health advisory of 20 ppt for any combination of PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFHpA, and PFNA.
Requires companies found responsible for contamination to pay for cleanups, monitoring, and to provide public drinking water to affected areas.

Added PFOS and PFOA to list of Chemicals of High Concern to Children, requiring manufacturers of children's products using the substances to follow disclosure and reporting requirements. The state can adopt rules regarding sale or distribution of specific products containing the chemicals.
Notes: PFOS was one of the original chemicals addressed by this regulation in 2014. PFOA was added as a chemical of high concern in 2019: https://www.healthvermont.gov/environment/children/chemicals-childrens-products.

Description: Bill would require water companies to notify customers when tests reveal that PFAS is present above notification limits defined in the bill.
Notes: SB 1013; Bill unanimously passed the Senate on Feb. 3, 2023, but a House subcommittee recommended tabling the bill on Feb. 13, 2023

Description: Law requires that the Board of Health review the recommendations of any work group convened after July 1, 2022, to study the occurrence of PFAS contaminants in public drinking water prior to adopting any regulations establishing maximum contaminant levels (MCLs).
Notes: HB 919; Signed into law on April 11, 2022

Description: Bill would prohibit the sale or manufacture of children's products known or believed to contain PFAS.
Notes: HB 1855; House committee voted to temporarily postpone consideration of the bill on Jan. 24, 2023

Description: Directs the State Board of Health to adopt regulations establishing maximum contaminant levels (MCLs) in public drinking water systems for perfluorooctanoic acid, perfluorooctane sulfonate, and for such other perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances, and other substances.

Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing or training purposes except at facilities that have implemented containment, treatment, and disposal measures to prevent uncontrolled environmental releases.
Directs a study of the occurrence of PFOA, PFOS, PFBA, PFHpA, PFHxS, PFNA, and other PFAS substances in the Commonwealth's public drinking water. Report due Dec. 1, 2021.
Follows EPA health guidance of 70 ppt for PFOA and PFOS.
The Department of Ecology announced that it plans to launch a AFFF collection and disposal program to collect PFAS-containing firefighting foam.
Notes: The program is expected to start at some point in 2023

Description: Proposed bill would ban the use of "toxic chemicals" in cosmetics, including PFAS.
Bill would require estbalishment of pollutant limits for PFAS in biosolids and establishment of testing requirements.

Proposed rule would create reporting requirements and restrictions for priority chemicals in priority consumer products. This includes PFAS in stain- and water-resistant treatments, carpets and rugs, and leather/textile furniture.
Notes: WSR 22-24-107; Proposed rule is in response to a 2019 law

Description: The Department of Ecology reported identifying safer alternatives to PFAS in carpets and rugs; leather and textile furnishings; and stain- and water-resistant treatments. The agency intends to initiate a rulemaking to implement the determinations.
Notes: Cycle 1, Phase 3. See also the department's rulemaking website.

Description: The Department of Ecology reported identifying safer alternatives to PFAS in five types of food packaging. The report sets in motion a two-year timeline that will see a ban on PFAS go into effect with those packaging types in May 2024.
Notes: News Release; Packing Affected: bags/sleeves, bowls, flat serviceware,  open-top containers, closed containers

Description: The Department of Ecology reported identifying safer alternatives to PFAS in four types of food packaging. The report sets in motion a two-year timeline that will see a ban on PFAS go into effect with those packaging types in early 2023.
Notes: Publication in Washington Register; Packing Affected: wraps/liners, plates, food boats, and pizza boxes

Description: Establishes firefighters' personal protective equipment as a "priority consumer product" for PFAS chemicals. Also established a fast-track process to restrict use of PFAS in consumer products listed in the November 2021 Final PFAS Action Plan (including carpets, furniture, and cosmetics). New rules to implement regulatory actions on these products must be adopted by Dec. 1, 2025.
Notes: HB 1694; Signed into law on March 31, 2022.

Description: Adopted rule sets new requirements for PFAS in public water supplies and establishes the administrative processes for setting drinking water quality standards as state action levels (SAL) and state maximum contaminant levels (MCLs). The proposal also establishes SALs for five PFAS contaminants: PFOA, PFOS, PFHxS, PFNA, and PFBS.
Adopted rule sets envrionmental laboratory data reporting requirements related to results from testing for PFAS in drinking water.
Published final Per- and Polyfluoralkyl Substances (PFAS) Chemical Action Plan that provides recommended actions to address PFAS contamination.
Bill would prohibit selling, making, or delivering cosmetics that contain 32 toxic ingredients, including all PFAS.
Partial ban of PFAS in food packaging.
Proposed non-binding joint legislative resolution asks the U.S. Department of Defense and other federal government entities for assistance in monitoring and mitigating PFAS in water supplies.
Ban on intentionally added PFAS substances in Class B firefighting foam used for testing or  training purposes. Also bans the manufacture, sale, and distribution of such foams in the state.
Notes: Legislation passed in 2020 expanded restrictions passed in 2018 to chemical plants, oil refineries, and oil terminals. The extended ban begins Jan. 1, 2024. Ban on PFAS-containing foam used in training began July 1, 2018. Ban on manufacture, sale, and distribution of PFAS-containing firefighting foam began July 1, 2020. See below entry for more information on expanded restrictions.

Description: Eliminates exemptions from restrictions on the use of PFAS in firefighting foam.
Directs the Department of Ecology to identify priority chemicals and priority products, to reduce toxic exposure.
Notes: Amended again in 2020 with a technical revision bill reorganizing environment statutes.

Description: Bill would require the development of a PFAS action plan for contaminated public water systems. It would also require chemical and manufacturing facilities to report use of PFAS.
Establishes certification of training programs and standards for the use of Class B firefighting foams containing PFAS.
Bill would direct the Department of Public Health to propose maximum contaminant levels for certain PFAS pollutants and create the West Virginia PFAS Action Response Team.
Law prohibits the use of Class B firefighting foams containing PFAS except for fire prevention, in emergencies, or at a properly equipped training/testing facility.
Notes: HB 2722; Signed into law on April 21, 2021

Description: Follows EPA health guidance of 70 ppt for PFOA and PFOS.
Proposed rule would amend NR 140 to add preventative action limits and enforcement standards for certain PFAS in groundwater.
Notes: The Wisconsin Natural Resources Board approved the statement of scope for the proposed rule (DG-17-22) on Dec. 14, 2022

Description: Creates chapter NR 159 to regulate fire fighting foam that contains intentionally added PFAS.
Notes: This permanent rule (WA-07-20) replaces the emergency rule approved Dec. 4, 2020, on the same topic. Rule text approved by governor and transmitted to legislature in February 2022.

Description: Amends various rules to limit PFAS in most surface water that supports fish to 8 parts per trillion (ppt) for PFOS. PFOA surface water limits set at 20 ppt for public water supplies and 95 ppt for other surface waters.
Notes: Republicans in the state legislature said in June 2022 they wouldn't block the rule.

Description: Amends NR 809 to establish drinking water maximum contaminant levels for perfluorooctanesulfonic acid (PFOS) and perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA).
Notes: Natural Resources Board approved the proposed rule (DG-24-19) at Feb. 23, 2022, board meeting but amended maximum contaminant level standards from 20 parts per trillion (ppt) to 70 ppt. Republicans in the state legislature said in June 2022 they wouldn't block the rule.

Description: Proposed rule would amend NR 140 to establish new state public health related groundwater quality standards for various substances, including perfluorooctane sulfonate (PFOS) and perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA).
Notes: Natural Resources Board failed to approve the proposed rule (SS 090-19/DG-15-19) on a 3-3 vote at Feb. 23, 2022, board meeting.

Description: PFAS fish consumption advisory issued after elevated levels of PFAS found in brown trout. Regulators recommend consuming no more than one meal per week of brown trout harvested from Wisconsin's Black Earth Creek.
Proposed rule would establish narrative surface water criteria and analytical methods for PFAS including PFOA and PFOS.
Notes: Multi-year rulemaking (SS 091-19/WY-23-19). Rulemaking hearing to be held Dec. 10, 2021.

Description: Announced intent to create drinking water maximum contaminant levels for 12 individual PFAS substances and four combined PFAS substances.
Notes: Rulemaking (SS 030-21/DG-31-20) will be a multi-year process. Preliminary public hearing held June 4, 2021.

Description: Emergency rule details appropriate handling of firefighting foams containing PFAS. It was passed by the Wisconsin Natural Resources Board in late October and adds more definition to law that went into effect Sept. 1, 2020.
Notes: A legislative committee rejected parts of the emergency rule in a hearing Dec. 18, 2020. Comments on the emergency rule are being accepted through 1/22/2021. Department of Natural Resources solicited input on an economic impact analysis, comments due Aug. 21, 2021. See proposed rule for permanent adoption above.

Description: Announced intent to establish new state groundwater quality standards for 22 substances including individual standards for six pesticides, individual standards for 12 per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), and combined standards for four PFAS.
Recommended health-based groundwater quality standards for PFOA and PFOS with enforcement standard of 20 ppt and recommended preventive action limit of 2 ppt.
Notes: The Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources asked the Department of Health Services to recommend groundwater quality standards. These recommendations were delivered in November 2020. DNR announced its intent to begin rulemaking in March 2021.

Description: Multi-agency action plan issued to guide the remdiation of existing environmental damage caused by per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, or PFAS, and limit their future use. The plan contains 25 specific actions and fulfills a requirement contained in a 2019 executive order issued by the governor.
Published survey results found that 77% of responding fire departments in the state purchased, stored, trained with or used PFAS-containing firefighting foam at some point in the past.
Restricts use of firefighting foams containing PFAS.
Notes: The state's Natural Resources Board authorized the State's Department of Natural Resources to complete emergency/permanent rules to implement the act in June 2020.

Description: Governor executive order pledging to create regulations on PFAS chemicals in the environment. The order also created a multi-agency council to identify sources of PFAS and inform the public.
Conducting review of potential PFOA and PFOS contamination at sites throughout the state.
Notes: A spokeswoman said, "We're working to identify an inventory of locations and whether they pose a risk to ground water."
